git.question: Which setting determines what pager is used when Git pages output?
git.answer: core.pager

git.question: What is the best way to characterize the git commit structure?
git.answer: Data snapshot

git.question: What is the difference between Git and SVN?
git.answer: SVN is a centralized system, while Git is a distributed system.

git.question: What are untracked files?
git.answer: files in the working directory that Git does not know about because they have not been staged or committed

git.question: How can you check your current git version?
git.answer: git --version

git.question:
What files is this .gitignore programmed to leave out? #.swift
build/

*.txt
*.metadata
git.answer: All files in the build directory, as well as files ending with .txt or .metadata

git.question: Your current project has several branches; master, beta, and push-notifications. You've just finished the notification feature in the push-notification branch, and you want to commit it to beta branch. How can you accomplish this?
git.answer: Checkout the beta branch and run git merge push-notifications

git.question: What situation can occur when attempting to combine branches containing changes to the same piece of code?
git.answer: merge conflict

git.question: What does the -p option add to the output of the git log command?
git.answer: It adds patch output that shows the differences introduced in each commit.

git.question: You have just completed rebasing your master branch and need to manually update the remote master, even though there is a merge conflict. How can you accomplish this?
git.answer: git push --force-with-lease

git.question: How can you exclude untracked files within the working directory from a Git repository?
git.answer: Add a pattern matching the files to the .gitignore file.

git.question: Consider the following Git workflow: following options is correct ?
git.answer: 1. Master 2. Hotfix 3. Develop 4. Feature 5. Release

git.question: What change will the following command make to the staging area files? git rm --cached testfile.js
git.answer: testfile.js will be removed from the staging area but its changes will still be tracked.

git.question: How do you save a search that you use often using GitHub?
git.answer: Click Save on the search results page.

git.question: Explain the concept of "Git blame" and when it is used in a version control workflow.
git.answer: Git blame is a tool for displaying who last modified each line of a file, helping to track changes and understand code history and authorship.

git.question: What information does the git config file store?
git.answer: local and global repository options

git.question: After accidentally deleting a branch in your local repository, how can you recover it?
git.answer: Find the hash of the branch with the reflog command, then execute git checkout -b <branchname> <hash>

git.question: What command lets you create a connection between a local and remote repository?
git.answer: git remote add origin

git.question: How can you display a list of files added or modified in a specific commit?
git.answer: Use the diff-tree command with the commit hash.

git.question: How does Git internally manage branches?
git.answer: by creating a pointer to the most recent snapshot/commit for the branch

git.question: You’re creating an action for the GitHub Marketplace. Why is it important to create a release?
git.answer: To package your software so that it can become available through the Github Marketplace

git.question: Where are files stored before they are committed to the local repository?
git.answer: Staging area

git.question: What is GitHub?
git.answer: A hosting platform for Git repositories

git.question: In GitHub Projects, how can you assign an issue to a collaborator?
git.answer: Select their username from the Assignees field.

git.question:
After checking your git status you get the following output, which shows the file beta-notes.js in the commit but also unstaged. How can this situation occur? Change to be committed:

(use "git reset HEAD <file>..." to unstage)
modified: beta-notes.js
Changes not staged for commit:
(use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
(use "git checkout --<file>..." to discard changes in working directory)

modified: beta-notes.js
git.answer: beta-notes.js was staged, then modified afterwards, creating two different versions of the file
The current branch's HEAD is reset back five commits, then prior commits are squashed into a single commit.

git.question: What does the git stash drop command do?
git.answer: removes the most recent stash entry

git.question: What is the difference between git branch -d and git branch -D?
git.answer: -d deletes the local branch, while -D deletes the local branch regardless of push and merge status.

git.question: What is the best way to report a bug to a GitHub project?
git.answer: Search for the bug in the project's existing issues and create a new one if it hasn't been reported yet.

git.question: How many ways are present in Git to integrate changes from one branch into another?
You want to perform a git reset but cannot recall all of the available options. What command would you use to see a description of them?
git.answer: git help reset

git.question: After mistakenly staging a file named myFile to the index, how would you remove it from the index to exclude it from your next commit?
git.answer: Use git reset myFile.txt.

git.question: Assigning an issue to a person implies that they ____
git.answer: are responsible for resolving the issue

git.question: How can you get better suggestions when creating functions?
git.answer: Type “function” and then add a detailed and expressive function name.

git.question: What feature does the shortcut /table activate when used inside a GitHub comment section?
git.answer: A markdown table structure

git.question: What is the difference between using the git stash and git stash pop commands?
git.answer: git stash creates a stash entry, while git stash pop places a saved state from the stash list onto the working directory

git.question: After pushing commits to the remote repository for the first time using the command below, what shorthand command can you use in future? git push -u origin master
git.answer: git push

git.question: Which option enables inclusion of committer name in custom log format?
git.answer: %cn

git.question: Which command would remove a file named wrongfile from the current branch of a repository, the index, and working files?
git.answer:
git rm wrongfile
git commit -m "Removed file"

git.question: You’re reviewing a file in a repository and want to link to the current version of the file, even if it gets updated later. How can you achieve this?
git.answer: Click Permalink on the code view

git.question: If you cloned an existing git repository, what would happen?
git.answer: A copy of the repository would be created on your local machine

git.question: What is the fastest way to start a search using Github web pages?
git.answer: Click the search box and type your searc query.

git.question: While working on a feature branch you try to use "git rerere" to solve a recurring merge conflict but nothing is happening. What could be causing this issue?
git.answer: "rerere.enabled" isn't enable in the config file.

git.question: What does refs store?
git.answer: Branch name

git.question: What practice can help reduce the chances of encountering a merge conflict?
git.answer: Keep local repository branches in sync with upstream branches in the remote repository by committing,pushing and pulling frequently.

git.question: What is the command to set the user email for the current repository?
git.answer: git config user.email

git.question: How would you create a custom shortcut or command across your Git environment?
git.answer: Create an alias using the git config command.

git.question: What Git workflow is used by teams that collaborate on a single branch and avoid creating long-lived development branches?
git.answer: Mainline flow

git.question:
Looking at the following commands, describe what is happening.
git checkout feature-user-location
git cherry-pick kj2342134sdf090093f0sdgasdf99sdfo992mmmf9921231
git.answer: The branch is switched to the feature-user-location branch, and the specified commit is applied to the branch.

git.question:
What happens if you run this command from your master branch?
git checkout -b beta-test
git.answer: A new branch called beta-test will be created and switched to.

git.question: After modifying some existing files in a repository, you decide to discard the changes. What command can you use?
git.answer: git checkout

git.question: What option can you use to apply git configurations across your entire git environment?
git.answer: --global

git.question: What is the main issue with using git rebase when working with multiple developers?
git.answer: Rebase affects only your repository and creates a diff in the master branch.

git.question: You stashed three sets of changes but cannot remember the contents of the first stash entry. What command would you use to see the details of the changes in the first of the three stash entries?
git.answer: git stash show -p

git.question: After making a commit, you notice that you forgot to include changes to the doge.txt file. What command or commands would you use to add the changes to the commit?
git.answer:
git add doge.txt
  git commit --amend --no-edit

git.question: What are two ways to help Copilot give you more accurate suggestions?
git.answer: Add context in comments. & Use descriptive function names.

git.question: You're looking at a repository page and click a folder name to open it. You have code search on, so you land in the code view. What is the quickest way to find a file on a path in your repo?
git.answer: Press the slash(/) key and then the T key.

git.question: Suppose you have created a bug fix on a new branch and want it to become part of the next production build generated from the main branch. What should you do next?
git.answer: Create a pull request to merge your new branch into the main branch.

git.question: What commands would you use to force an overwrite of your local files with the master branch?
git.answer:
git fetch --all
  git reset --hard origin/master

git.question: How would you describe a forked repository?
git.answer: a separate copy of a repository

git.question: When is the cherry-pick command used?
git.answer: when a commit from one branch needs to be copied into another branch

git.question: Your company has moved its remote repository to GitHub at this location: https://github.com/yourcompany/core-api.git. What command updates the remote repository, named origin, to point to the new remote repository at this location?
git.answer: git remote set-url origin https://github.com/yourcompany/core-api.git

git.question: Why would you use a pre-receive hook in your remote repository?
git.answer: To execute a script when a remote receives a push that is triggered before any refs are updated

git.question: What features do repository managers such as GitHub provide beyond Git?
git.answer: Repository managers provide an online service for hosting Git repositories that include collaboration features such as pull requests, issue tracking, and peer reviews.

git.question: You are working on a project that uses a Python library and you want to find an example of how to use a function across all public repositories. Which part of GitHub’s platform would you use?
git.answer: Search

git.question: Which use case is NOT a good candidate for a Git hook?
git.answer: state dependent environment changes

git.question: What would happen if you ran the git reset testfile.js command?
git.answer: testfile.js would be reverted to its last saved copy.

git.question: _ will rewind your project to a specific point in time, losing all commits that came after it. _ will keep changes in those rewound commits as local modifications
git.answer: git reset --hard; git reset --soft

git.question: What command would let you modify your previous commit?
git.answer: --amend

git.question: Working late on a project, you need to find an issue that was assigned to you. What query do you type?
git.answer: Is:issue assignee:username

git.question: Which command correctly creates a lightweight tag?
git.answer: git tag v3.8.1

git.question: After starting to merge a feature branch into your master branch, you encounter a merge conflict and decide you do not want to perform the merge. How can you stop the merge and restore to the pre-merge state?
git.answer: Use git merge --abort.

git.question: After you've successfully merged two branches and committed the changes, what is the next step in keeping your git structure organized?
git.answer: Run git branch -d <branch name> to delete the merged branch.

git.question: While pushing changes to a remote repository, you receive the following message. How do you resolve this issue?
git.answer: Execute a pull, then resolve any merge conflicts and execute another push.

git.question: What statement best describes Git's concept of HEAD?
git.answer: a pointer to the most recent commit in the currently checked-out branch

git.question: What command takes changes from the master branch on the remote repository origin and merges then to the local checked-out branch?
git.answer: git pull origin master

git.question: Which option enables inclusion of author name in custom log format?
git.answer: %an

git.question: What does commit object contain?
git.answer: Reference to parent commit objects and a set of files, representing the state of a project at a given point of time, and an SHA1 name, a 40-character string that uniquely identifies the commit object.

git.question: While modifying a file, you're unexpectedly assigned an urgent bug fix on another branch. How can you temporarily save your local work without committing?
git.answer: Use git stash to save your work and come back later and reapply the stashed commit.

git.question: After making some major changes to your code, you are a little nervous about committing. What command would you use to review the commit prior to making it?
git.answer: git commit --dry-run

git.question: Which of the following is true of the git push command?
git.answer: By default a push doesn't send tags to the remote repository.

git.question: Why should you include a descriptive function name when writing code with Copilot?
git.answer: It helps Copilot have better context for code assistance and generation.

git.question: After a recent release with a stack trace, an issue is create that indicates the problem is with a newly added configuration property named MaxConnections. What command can find all commits that add or remove the string MaxConnections?
git.answer: git log -S "MaxConnections"

git.question:
What is the operation doing given the Git commands below? git bisect start
git bisect bad 5d41402abc4b2a76b9719d911017c592
git bisect good 69faab6268350295550de7d587bc323d
git.answer: It performs a binary search using a known bad commit and known good commit to determine which commit introduced a bug

git.question: What command finds the HEAD of the current branch?
git.answer: git show-ref --head

git.question: How does Git think of its data?
git.answer: Snapshot

git.question: Which key press returns a set of suggestions to pick from, when writing a Git command?
git.answer: Tab

git.question: Git Pull is a combination of?
git.answer: fetch and merge.

git.question: How would you configure Git to abort a commit if a smoke test script fails?
git.answer: Create a pre-commit hook to trigger the script.

git.question: What is the difference between a soft reset (git reset --soft) and a hard reset (git reset –hard) ?
git.answer: A soft reset only changes the commit that HEAD points to, while a hard reset resets the index and working tree to match the specified commit, discarding any changes.

git.question: You are working on an AI app and need to add information on project tables about the AI model being targeted. What feature allows you to do this?
git.answer: Custom fields

git.question: After staging a series of changes to the index, which command could you use to review them prior to a commit?
git.answer: git diff --cached

git.question: Which of the following is called dumb protocol?
git.answer: HTTP

git.question: What is the difference between initializing a normal repo and a bare repo?
git.answer: Bare repos do not come with working or checked-out source files.

git.question: You’re in the repo for a specific project while working on an app module. You want to look for some of the docs you’ve been working on, which you wrote in markdown. To quickly look in your own repo for all files with a markdown extension, press the slash (/) button on the keyboard while on the repository page and type ___.
git.answer: Code:*.md

git.question: How would you delete a remote branch in your repository?
git.answer: Use git push <remote_name> --delete <branch_name>

git.question: What conflicts can occur when forcing a push after rebasing?
git.answer: The remote master branch could have existing changes overwritten.

git.question: What type of Git hook could be used to validate that a commit message contains a ticket number?
git.answer: commit-msg

git.question: What is a remote repository?
git.answer: a version of the repository hosted on the internet or network that is pushed to or pulled from by collaborators

git.question: What is the default setting of git reflog when no subcommands are specified?
git.answer: show

git.question: What command would you use to create a new git repository?
git.answer: git init

git.question: You're creating an action for the Github marketplace. why is it importance to create a release?
git.answer: to alow you to create .zip files that you can easily share & to package your software so that it can become available through the Github marketplace

git.question: Which user should be created first during setting up of SSH?
git.answer: None of these

git.question: What command displays the difference between the working tree and the stage/index area, as well as files not tracked by Git?
git.answer: git status

git.question: How could you squash multiple commits together without using git merge --squash?
git.answer: Rebasing

git.question: What information do Git reflogs (reference logs) store?
git.answer: updates to branch tips and other references in the local repository

git.question: What command would you use to stage changes to the index strictly for properties files in the current directory?
git.answer: git add *.properties

git.question: How would you display a histogram showing inserts, deletion, and modifications per file for a specific commit along with its general commit information?
git.answer: Use git show <commit> --stat

git.question: Which version onwards did Git offer reversing a file back to what it looked like when last committed?
You find a bug in your project, but can't locate where it was introduced in the commit history. How would you diagnose this problem?
git.answer: Use git bisect to compare the buggy commit to an early commit that works as expected.

git.question: You would like to restore some previously stashed work to a new branch. How can you do that?
git.answer: Run git stash branch <branch name>

git.question: Which command will list tags with the 1.4.2 series?
git.answer: git tag -l 'v1.4.2.*'

git.question: You have changed your mind about adding broccoli to your project. How should you remove it?
git.answer: git clean -f

git.question: Which of the following is an integration manager?
git.answer: Depends upon project type

git.question: Which Git command begins tracking of a new file?
git.answer: add

git.question: Which of these terms best describes Git?
git.answer: Distributed Version Control System

git.question: What is the purpose of C++ move constructor, and when is it automatically generated?
git.answer: A move constructor allows efficient transfer of resources from one object to another,reducing unnecessary copying.

git.question: Which command can be used to list the branches that have been merged into the currently checked-out branch?
git.answer: git branch --merged

git.question: You’re organizing a desktop application project. You want to use an overview f your project statuses and be able to drag and drop issues. Which view would you use?
git.answer: Board

git.question: Which option on the git log command allows you to limit output to commits made after certain date?
git.answer: --since

git.question: Which strategy is used by Git for merging two branches?
git.answer: octopus

git.question: What is version control?
git.answer: a system that shows, tracks, and controls changes to a set of files over time

git.question:
What does the following command do to the git repository?
git reset --soft HEAD^
git.answer: It sets HEAD to the previous commit and leaves changes from the undone commit in the stage/index.

git.question: Your team lead needs a list of all commits that will be moved before you perform a rebase. Which command can you use to access that information?
git.answer: git rebase -i

git.question: While doing a code review, you want to start an issue by highlighting a function that takes up several lines of code. What is the fastest way to do this in code view?
git.answer: Click the line number with the function and select reference function in an issue

git.question: What is the main purpose of the Chat panel?
git.answer: To have a conversational discussion with the AI behind Copilot

git.question: What command creates a new branch from the currently checked-out branch?
git.answer: git checkout -b <nameOfBranch>

git.question: What does a Template repository do?
git.answer: It allows you to create a default structure and files based on the current repository.

git.question: What is usually the extension of file which has the public key?
git.answer: pub

git.question: Why would the following command be used? git rebase -i HEAD~10
git.answer: To list the last 10 commits and modify them with either the squash or fixup command

git.question: How does the -p option change the behavior of the git add command
git.answer: It allows developers to interactively choose which changes to tracked files are staged and outputs the differences for review.

git.question: What command can you use to remove untracked files from the working directory?
git.answer: git clean -d -f

git.question: After you make changes to a local repository, you run the following command. What will this do? git commit -a -m "Refactor code base"
git.answer: Adds all modified files to the staging area, then commits them with a message

git.question: In a situation where you have several commits for a single task, what is the most efficient way to restructure your commit history?
git.answer: Squash the related commits together into a single coherent commit.

git.question: What is the difference between git fetch and git pull
git.answer: git fetch updates remote tracking branches with changes from a remote repository, while git pull updates remote tracking branches with changes from a remote repository and merges them into their corresponding local branches.

git.question: What is the staging area or index?
git.answer: an area that stores information about changes that will be included in the next commit

git.question: Which of these is not a label that github creates by default?
git.answer: repo

git.question: What command creates a near-exact copy of the entire repository from a server?
git.answer: git clone <url>

git.question: After checking out a specific commit, you receive a warning message indicating You are in 'detached HEAD' state. What is Git warning you of?
git.answer: The commit does not have a parent.

git.question: When Git workflows contain a topic branch, what purpose does the topic branch serve?
git.answer: Topic branches are short-lived branches used to store work related to a particular feature.

git.question:
What will the following command print to the Terminal?
git remote -v
git.answer: A list of remote repositories and their URLs

git.question: After staging changes to several files, you realize the changes to the config.properties file are incorrect, and need to be removed from the stage and working directory. What command can you use to remove the staged changes to the file?
git.answer: git reset HEAD^ -- config.properties

git.question: What does the RUN command do in a Dockerfile?
git.answer: It allows you to execute a shell command during the image generation process

git.question: This command is an example of what kind of tag? git tag -a v1.4 -m "ABCD v1.5"
git.answer: annotated

git.question: What is the difference between git stash pop and git stash apply?
git.answer: git stash pop applies the topmost entry in the stash to the working files and removes it from the stash, while git stash apply applies the topmost entry in the stash to the working files but leaves it in the stash.

git.question: You find that your project has a tag and branch both named push-notifications, which causes confusion when trying to print out given reference. How can you specify which branch you want to look at?
git.answer: use git show refs/head/push-notifications

git.question: What Language is used in GIT?
git.answer: C

git.question: How many individual commits can a single repository have?
git.answer: any number of commits

git.question: What types of tags does Git support?
git.answer: lightweight and annotated

git.question: When Git Workflows contain a long-running branch, what purpose does the long-running branch serve?
git.answer: Long-running branches correspond to different stages of development and are always open for topic/feature branches to be pulled into.

git.question:
Which of the following is true when you use the following command?
git add -A
git.answer: All new and updated files are staged

git.question: How would you delete unreachable objects older than a specified time from your project database?
git.answer: git prune --expire <time>

git.question:
What is the status of the beta-notes.js file in the following output? Changes not staged for commit:
(use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
(use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)

modified: beta-notes.js
git.answer: beta-notes.js is a tracked file and has been modified, but has not been added to the current commit.
